captions.text: Ah, doesn't this take you back. Around mid-2007 I was living in a drainpipe licking the backs
of Cornetto lids for sustenance and one night I'd scraped together enough pennies to afford
to spend the night at the YMCA. After agreeing to be viciously buggered in return for being
I'm not sure if I'm allowed to go on the communal PS3, I played a demo for a game called
The Darkness with a silly opening sequence and a slightly obtuse puzzle that I couldn't get
past.
So after Big Steve chased me off so he could play the new Ratchet and Clank, I scrounged
up some yellow craft paper, made some figurines from stolen Burger King napkins and produced
a short internet video explaining how I'm really clever and therefore the game must
be dumb.
Who would have thought that that event would lead me to where I am today?
Now I have Cornetto Lids beyond the dreams of avarice and I'm the one paying to viciously
bugger Big Steve.
And I'm now professional enough to play a game for more than ten minutes before I attempt
I don't think it's time to sabotage its developers' retirement plans, unless it's Final Fantasy, or Monster Hunter, or I'm Bored, or in a Bad Mood, or it's Thursday.
Anyway, after all that, The Darkness turned out to be not a bad game, apparently.
I didn't play it myself, because it was Thursday.
Not that it matters, because the original developers, Starbreeze, have mysteriously vanished from the credits of TheDarkness 2 in favour of the chaps who made Dark Sector.
Which you can't say doesn't make at least some kind of sense.

But it means despite being a direct sequel Darkness 2 has a significantly different feel to the first Like when a soap opera character disappears for a few weeks and comes back played by a different slightly older actor who doesn get so uppity about minimum wage Jackie Estacado now looks less like Benicio del Toro doing shampoo adverts and more like
a generic fashion model who has a complicated relationship with his hairdresser.
In the years since the first game, Jackie has become the head of his crime family, living
a life of wealth, power and glamour until he is hit by an assassination attempt which
he only survives by doing what I think we'd all do in the same situation, awaken the ancient
demonic power that dwells within him and mints up his attackers with the tentacles.
And Jackie continues living a life of wealth, power and glamour, but now with angry black
snakes growing out of his shoulders.
Fucking 1%!
Darkness 2 is again a first-person shooter, but eschews Darkness 1's gritty, realistic
look in favour of that colourful, semi-cell-shaded comic book style as previously seen in such
games as Borderlands and Cassie, which I find I don't like very much, especially in games
like Darkness 2 where the characters have realistic proportions where everyone looks like some
kind of papercraft model and they drew their facial features on with wax crayons.
What's also different from Darkness 1 is that what was once a big clump of playdough has
now been vigorously rolled between some palms into a big linear sausage.
No more sidequests or hub travel, just a linear sequence of missions, and while in the first
you summoned several imps with different abilities, only one of the little fucks showed up for
this party.
But while comparing it to the original is perfectly valid and clever and handsome, it's
also slightly unfair, because they're trying to do different things.
Darkness 2 goes less for exploration but may have a somewhat tighter focus.
Why you gotta be so down on a new developer leaving their mark on a property, you asshole?

The combat takes a somewhat spectacle approach since you get more points for creative kills and there never any shortage of real go mooks whose dreams of promotion utterly blind them to the fact that you already bitten off enough limbs to start a analyze other versions I think I get much
The game is a bit more like the original, but it's a bit more like the original.
I'm not sure if I would have been more into a Rainbow Six game if the option was there
to pick up one of your squadmates and throw them at an enemy in order to instigate a forced
piggyback ride.
On top of that, there's a strong character-based story focus and it's competently put together,
golf clap, golf clap.
But if there's nothing particularly wrong with DARKNESS 2, then why is my outstretched
palm still indifferently horizontal?
We need to go deeper, fellow surgeons of the cultural operating table, and back-engineer
this gut feeling.
It could be that it's just too short, presumably to make room for a singularly out-of-place
co-op campaign in which you play a hilarious international stereotype so stupidly overpowered
the gameplay turns into who can reach the baddies first.
It happens in parallel to the main plot, but the main plot is about an angsty murderer
being slowly reduced to half a pound of mints by a psychotic torture cult, while an evil
dark power conspires to keep him in a state of constant emotional torment, so excuse me
if I feel the fat drunken Scotsman with an axe is undermining the established tone a
wee bit.
In Never Leaving Jackie's perspective, the singleplayer campaign feels like a very personal

journey and there are even moments when the darkness induces hallucinations to make him question reality and the co undermines that too Oh I guess this is reality after all cos there a voodoo priest and a samurai summoning black holes and actually let double check that It could also be that Wacky Jackie just hard to get over Oh wait that F DeixaOwa attachedri
¢''¦ Jean hi, you have made a living!
The glorification of violent revenge and masses of homoerotic sadomasochism.
Mercifully though, not so many women proportioned like iced lollies balanced on two chicken drumsticks,
standing around like God gave them a vicious Chinese burn around their waists.
Thanks for watching!
